[[Fellow of the Royal Society]], }} '''David George Kendall''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Kingman | first1 = J. | authorlink = John Kingman| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.2008.0017 | title = David George Kendall. 15 January 1918 -- 23 October 2007 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 55 | pages = 121 | year = 2009 | pmid = | pmc = }} (15 January 1918 – 23 October 2007) was an [[English people|English]] [[statistician]] and [[mathematician]], known for his work on probability, statistical shape analysis, ley lines and queueing theory. He spent most of his academic life in the [[University of Oxford]] (1946–1962) and the [[University of Cambridge]] (1962–1985). He worked with [[M. S. Bartlett]] during World War II, and visited [[Princeton University]] after the war.{{MacTutor|id=Kendall|title=David George Kendall}} ==Life and career== David George Kendall was born on 15 January 1918 in [[Ripon]], [[West Riding of Yorkshire]], and attended [[Ripon Grammar School]] before attending [[Queen's College, Oxford]], graduating in 1939.{{Citation | first1=G. | last1=Grimmett | authorlink1 =Geoffrey Grimmett | year=2008 | title = David George Kendall | arxiv=0810.1091}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Bingham | first1 = N. H. | title = A conversation with David Kendall | doi = 10.1214/ss/1032280213 | journal = Statistical Science | volume = 11 | issue = 3 | pages = 159 | year = 1996 | pmid = | pmc = }} He worked on [[rocket]]ry during the [[second world war|war]], before moving to [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]], [[Oxford University|Oxford]], in 1946. In 1962 he was appointed the first [[Professorship of Mathematical Statistics, University of Cambridge|Professor of Mathematical Statistics]] in the [[Statistical Laboratory, University of Cambridge]]; in which post he remained until his retirement in 1985. He was elected to a professorial fellowship at [[Churchill College, Cambridge|Churchill College]], and he was a founding trustee of the [[Rollo Davidson Prize|Rollo Davidson Trust]]. In 1986, he was awarded an Honorary Degree (Doctor of Science) by the [[University of Bath]].{{cite web |url= http://www.bath.ac.uk/ceremonies/hongrads/ |title=Honorary Graduates 1989 to present | publisher = [[University of Bath]] |work=bath.ac.uk |accessdate=18 February 2012}} Kendall was an expert in [[probability]] and data analysis, and pioneered [[statistical shape analysis]] including the study of [[ley lines]]. He defined [[Kendall's notation]] for [[queueing theory]]. The [[Royal Statistical Society]] awarded him the [[Guy Medal]] in Silver in 1955, followed in 1981 by the Guy Medal in Gold. In 1980 the [[London Mathematical Society]] awarded Kendall their [[Senior Whitehead Prize]], and in 1989 their [[De Morgan Medal]].{{Citation |url = http://www.lms.ac.uk/activities/prizes_com/pastwinners.html |title = List of Prizewinners |author = London Mathematical Society |accessdate = 2007-07-08}} He was elected a fellow of the [[Royal Society]] in 1964. He was married to Diana Fletcher from 1952 until his death. They had two sons and four daughters, including [[Wilfrid Kendall]], professor in the Department of Statistics at the [[University of Warwick]] and reporter [[Bridget Kendall]] [[Order of the British
